para.text: The requirement for program approval by the Maryland Higher Education Commission does not apply to:
Programs conducted by individuals, firms, corporations, or other organizations exclusively for their own employees;
Apprenticeship and other training offered by unions for their members; and
Individual instructors who go to various places to offer instruction to not more than one individual.
The exclusion in §A(1) of this regulation does not apply to firms, corporations, or organizations if they enroll individuals other than their own employees.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Board" means the Maryland Board of Nursing.
"Certified medicine aide (CMA)" means a CNA who:
Is a geriatric nursing assistant as required by COMAR 10.07.02.44;
Has successfully completed a course meeting the criteria of COMAR 10.07.02.44;
Functions in a setting licensed under COMAR 10.07.02; and
Performs the delegated nursing function of medication administration under the direct supervision of a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse.
Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA).
"Certified nursing assistant (CNA)" means an individual, regardless of title, who routinely performs nursing tasks delegated by an RN or LPN for compensation.
"Certified nursing assistant (CNA)" does not include:
A medication technician; or
An individual who merely provides assistance with activities of daily living unless the client's needs are such that adverse health consequences are predictable.

"Classroom laboratory training" means instruction and demonstration, on an individual or a mannequin, of patient care skills by an instructor and return demonstration of competence in these skills by the student.

"Clinical facility" means a setting where clients are present and that provides facilities for clinical training experiences of nursing assistants, with the faculty of the program responsible for planning, implementing, and evaluating these experiences.
"Controlling institution" means an organization that offers a nursing assistant training program.
"Direct supervision" means that the registered nurse or licensed practical nurse is physically present while the trainee demonstrates patient care skills.
"Geriatric nursing assistant competency examination (GNA-CE)" means an examination that meets the criteria set by 42 CFR §483.154 to determine entry level competence for a GNA.
“Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN)” means an individual who:
Is licensed by the Board to practice licensed practical nursing; or
Has a multistate licensure privilege to practice licensed practical nursing.
“Medication technician” means an individual who has completed a 20-hour course in medication administration approved by the Board.
“Multistate licensure privilege” has the meaning set forth in COMAR 10.27.01.01B.
"Program completion" means that the trainee achieves a passing grade on the theory and clinical portions of the training program and on the comprehensive final examination.
“Registered nurse (RN)” means an individual who:
Is licensed by the Board to practice registered nursing; or
Has a multistate licensure privilege to practice registered nursing.

“Supervised clinical training” means training in a clinical facility in which the trainee demonstrates knowledge and skills while performing tasks on an individual under the direct supervision of an RN or an LPN.
"Written agreement" means a contract with a clinical facility outlining the terms required, by both the program and the facility, for clinical training of student nursing assistants.
Approval Requirements.
All training programs shall be approved by the Board.

In addition to the requirement stated in §A(1) of this regulation, all programs shall be approved by the Maryland Higher Education Commission or Department of Education except those excluded under COMAR Title 13B.
The approval process shall be completed before the training program is offered.
An organization wishing to offer a nursing assistant training program shall:
Submit to the Board a proposal demonstrating compliance with the requirements stated in Regulations .04—.08 of this chapter; and
Contact the Board to obtain the training program requirements and a program application packet.
The program proposal shall:
Demonstrate that the length of time for the program is adequate for trainees to be successful in achieving the program objectives; and
State the criteria for successful program completion including the required passing standard on the final examination.
The Board shall review programs for renewal of approval every 2 years.
The facility offering the training program shall:
Be accredited or approved by the appropriate agency; and
Have a statement of equal opportunity.

The controlling institution shall provide the financial support and resources needed to operate a program which meets the legal and educational requirements of the Board and fosters achievement of program objectives.
The financial resources provided by the controlling institution shall support:
The number of instructors adequate to ensure that each trainee is provided with a didactic and clinical program of learning that fosters achievement of program objectives;
Adequate educational facilities;
Appropriate equipment; and
Qualified administrative personnel.
Each course instructor shall:
Be a registered nurse licensed to practice registered nursing in Maryland or have a multistate licensure privilege to practice registered nursing in this State;
Have a minimum of 2 years of nursing experience, at least 1 year of which was in caring for the elderly or chronically ill in the past 5 years; and
Complete a course with a minimum of 16 hours of instruction in the principles of adult education, or have a minimum of 2 years of teaching experience.
Each program shall have an RN instructor who has overall supervisory responsibility for the operation of the program.
Instructors in CNA programs in Maryland public secondary schools shall meet the requirements under §A(1) and (2) of this regulation as well as those found in COMAR 13A.12.02.24A(1) and (2).
Responsibilities. The course instructor is responsible for:
Participating in development and evaluation of the training program;
Implementing the approved training program;
Supervising classroom laboratory experiences;
Evaluating student performance in the classroom; and
Providing supervision and clinical evaluation of each trainee at the clinical training site.
Other health professionals may teach selected portions of the curriculum that relate to the health professionals' area of expertise.
Physical Facilities. The physical facilities shall be adequate to meet the needs of the training program and shall include the following:
Adequate space for privacy of faculty-student conferences;
Classroom, laboratories, and conference rooms; and
Space for equipment and instructional materials.

Instructional Resources. Learning resources and instructional materials such as books, audiovisual materials, and computer software shall be current, accessible, and relevant to the role of the CNA and shall adhere to the following guidelines:
Clinical resources shall have a publication date not older than 5 years from the current year;
Texts and other resources selected shall be relevant to the curriculum and written at a level appropriate to nursing assistants; and
Acquisitions shall be selected with the participation of the nursing assistant faculty.
Clinical Facilities.
Facilities used for clinical learning experiences shall be approved by the appropriate government authorities.
Facilities with conditional or provisional approval status may not be used for student learning experiences.
The Board shall approve the use of each clinical facility before utilization for student experience.
There shall be a minimum of one instructor for each 8 students in the clinical area.
Clinical facilities shall meet the following requirements:
A sufficient number and variety of clients to provide training experiences for all students to achieve the stated objectives;
A sufficient number of RNs and other nursing personnel to ensure safe and continuous care of clients; and
Conformance with accepted standards of nursing care and practice.
Written Agreements.
The training program shall have a written agreement with any clinical facility that is not a part of the controlling institution.
Written agreements between the program and the cooperating facilities shall:
Be developed jointly with the clinical facility;
Be reviewed periodically;
Include provision for adequate notice of termination;
Specify the responsibility of the training program to the facility and the responsibility of the facility to the training program; and
Identify the functions and responsibilities of the parties involved.
The training program shall provide a minimum of 100 hours of instruction.
Of the 100 hours, a minimum of:
60 hours shall be devoted to didactic instruction and classroom laboratory practice; and
40 hours shall be devoted to clinical training experiences in a clinical facility.
Curriculum.
The following content areas shall form the framework of the curriculum:
Role of the CNA;
Infection control;
Safety and environment;
Mobility and positioning;
Elimination;
Data collection;
Hygiene;
Treatments;
Communication:
Observing, recording, and reporting;
Interpersonal relations; and
Legal and ethical considerations.
A training program shall provide at least 16 hours of classroom laboratory training before a trainee's direct assignment to client care. This instruction shall include the following topics:
Role of the CNA;
Infection control;
Safety and emergency procedures, including the Heimlich maneuver;
The environment;
Communication:
Observing, recording, and reporting;
Interpersonal relations; and
Legal and ethical considerations.
The training program shall identify the unit objectives and performance indicators for each of the areas in §C(1) of this regulation in its training criteria.
Each training program shall have an objective final examination that measures achievement of the performance indicators.
To successfully complete the program, each trainee shall:
Complete the approved training program;
Demonstrate the ability to perform nursing functions with clients of any age and with various levels of physical, sensory, cognitive, and emotional ability;
Pass a comprehensive written final examination; and
Demonstrate competence in meeting the objectives and performance indicators contained in the training requirements.
Each trainee shall be evaluated on their ability to meet the program objectives in the classroom, laboratory, and clinical setting.
Each program shall submit to the Board, on a quarterly basis, statistics on enrollments, program completions, and attrition rates.
The GNA-CE performance of candidates from each program shall be reviewed annually by the Board.
A program may not modify an approved curriculum without the Board's permission.
A program may not modify its faculty without the Board's permission.
The Board's professional staff may visit a program annually and provide a report to the Board.
The Board may withdraw approval from any program:
That fails to comply with a requirement of this regulation;
That discontinues its curriculum for a period exceeding 6 months; or
Whose graduates achieve less than 90 percent of the national success rate on the GNA-CE.
When the facility, institution, or individual considers closing a nursing assistant training program, the facility, institution, or individual shall:
Notify the Board in writing of the intended closing date; and
Continue the program until the committed class schedule of currently enrolled students is completed.
Custody of Student Records.

If the nursing assistant training program closes, but the controlling institution continues to function, the controlling institution shall assume responsibility for the records of the students and the graduates. The Board shall be advised of the arrangements made to safeguard the records.

If a controlling institution that has obtained a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission plans to cease operations, the institution shall file the records of students and graduates, or legible copies of those records, with the Maryland Higher Education Commission as required by Education Article, §11-401, Annotated Code of Maryland.

If a controlling institution that is not required to obtain Maryland Higher Education Commission approval plans to cease operations, the Board and the controlling institution shall reach a mutual agreement about the disposition of student records.
